https://www.thetimes.com/uk/article/tube.title: Tube protest was wrong, admits Extinction Rebellion activist
https://www.thetimes.com/uk/article/tube.text:
An Extinction Rebellion activist who enraged commuters by climbing on top of a Tube train admitted yesterday: “We got it wrong.”
Mark Ovland, 38, and his fellow protester James Mee, 37, unfurled a banner saying “business as usual = death” while angry passengers bombarded them with coins, coffee and sandwiches.
Mee was pulled on to the platform at Canning Town station in east London and kicked by commuters during the morning rush hour on October 17, 2019.
Edmund Blackman, prosecuting, said the pair were on top of the train for only 20 minutes but 48,000 people had their morning journeys disrupted.
After the men were given 12-month community orders, Ovland said: “We had the best of intentions but this time we got it wrong.”

https://www.thetimes.com/sport/football/.title: Protester has to be cut free with bolt cutters after tying himself to Everton goal
https://www.thetimes.com/sport/football/.text:
Everton’s crucial Premier League victory against Newcastle United on Thursday was held up for almost seven minutes when a protester tied himself to one of the goalposts.
The man, who has identified himself as 21-year-old student Louis McKechnie, entered the Goodison Park pitch early in the second half and attached himself to a post by wrapping what appeared to be a cable tie around his neck.
The match had to be paused while security staff attempted to remove McKechnie, who was wearing a T-shirt supporting a group called Just Stop Oil, from the pitch. The mechanical engineering student had to be cut loose with a pair of heavy duty bolt cutters.
